briefdescription.para: typedef for internals of message iterator
The DBusMessageLoader object encapsulates the process of converting a byte stream into a series of DBusMessage.

detaileddescription.para: It buffers the incoming bytes as efficiently as possible, and generates a queue of messages. DBusMessageLoader is typically used as part of a DBusTransport implementation. The DBusTransport then hands off the loaded messages to a DBusConnection, making the messages visible to the application.

xrefdescription.para: write tests for break-loader that a) randomly delete header fields and b) set string fields to zero-length and other funky values.

briefdescription.para: Implementation of the varargs arg-getting functions.

detaileddescription.para: dbus_message_get_args() is the place to go for complete documentation.

xrefdescription.para: This may leak memory and file descriptors if parsing fails. See #21259

parameterdescription.para: return location for first argument, followed by list of type/location pairs

simplesect.para: FALSE if error was set

briefdescription.para: An static string representing an empty signature.
Swaps the message to compiler byte order if required.
Gets the data to be sent over the network for this message.

detaileddescription.para: The header and then the body should be written out. This function is guaranteed to always return the same data once a message is locked (with dbus_message_lock()).

parameterdescription.para: return location for message header data.
return location for message body data.

briefdescription.para: Gets the unix fds to be sent over the network for this message.

detaileddescription.para: This function is guaranteed to always return the same data once a message is locked (with dbus_message_lock()).

parameterdescription.para: return location of unix fd array
return number of entries in array

briefdescription.para: Sets the serial number of a message.

detaileddescription.para: This can only be done once on a message.

DBusConnection will automatically set the serial to an appropriate value when the message is sent; this function is only needed when encapsulating messages in another protocol, or otherwise bypassing DBusConnection.

briefdescription.para: Adds a counter to be incremented immediately with the size/unix fds of this message, and decremented by the size/unix fds of this message when this message if finalized.

detaileddescription.para: The link contains a counter with its refcount already incremented, but the counter itself not incremented. Ownership of link and counter refcount is passed to the message.

briefdescription.para: Adds a counter to be incremented immediately with the size/unix fds of this message, and decremented by the size/unix fds of this message when this message if finalized.

simplesect.para: FALSE if no memory

briefdescription.para: Removes a counter tracking the size/unix fds of this message, and decrements the counter by the size/unix fds of this message.
Locks a message.

detaileddescription.para: Allows checking that applications don't keep a reference to a message in the outgoing queue and change it underneath us. Messages are locked when they enter the outgoing queue (dbus_connection_send_message()), and the library complains if the message is modified while locked. This function may also called externally, for applications wrapping D-Bus in another protocol.

memberdef.argsstring: (DBusMessage *message, int field, int typecode, const char *value)
memberdef.name: set_or_delete_string_field

briefdescription.para: Tries to get a message from the message cache.

detaileddescription.para: The retrieved message will have junk in it, so it still needs to be cleared out in dbus_message_new_empty_header()

simplesect.para: the message, or NULL if none cached

briefdescription.para: Tries to cache a message, otherwise finalize it.
Creates a new message loader.

detaileddescription.para: Returns NULL if memory can't be allocated.

simplesect.para: new loader, or NULL.

briefdescription.para: Increments the reference count of the loader.

simplesect.para: the loader

briefdescription.para: Decrements the reference count of the loader and finalizes the loader when the count reaches zero.
Gets the buffer to use for reading data from the network.

detaileddescription.para: Network data is read directly into an allocated buffer, which is then used in the DBusMessage, to avoid as many extra memcpy's as possible. The buffer must always be returned immediately using _dbus_message_loader_return_buffer(), even if no bytes are successfully read.

xrefdescription.para: this function can be a lot more clever. For example it can probably always return a buffer size to read exactly the body of the next message, thus avoiding any memory wastage or reallocs.
we need to enforce a max length on strings in header fields.

briefdescription.para: Returns a buffer obtained from _dbus_message_loader_get_buffer(), indicating to the loader how many bytes of the buffer were filled in.

detaileddescription.para: This function must always be called, even if no bytes were successfully read.

parameterdescription.para: number of bytes that were read into the buffer.

briefdescription.para: Gets the buffer to use for reading unix fds from the network.

detaileddescription.para: This works similar to _dbus_message_loader_get_buffer()

parameterdescription.para: the array to read fds into
how many fds to read at most

simplesect.para: TRUE on success, FALSE on OOM

briefdescription.para: Returns a buffer obtained from _dbus_message_loader_get_unix_fds().

detaileddescription.para: This works similar to _dbus_message_loader_return_buffer()

parameterdescription.para: the array fds were read into

memberdef.argsstring: (DBusMessageLoader *loader, DBusMessage *message, int byte_order, int fields_array_len, int header_len, int body_len)
memberdef.name: load_message

briefdescription.para: Converts buffered data into messages, if we have enough data.

detaileddescription.para: If we don't have enough data, does nothing.

xrefdescription.para: we need to check that the proper named header fields exist for each message type.
If a message has unknown type, we should probably eat it right here rather than passing it out to applications. However it's not an error to see messages of unknown type.

simplesect.para: TRUE if we had enough memory to finish.

briefdescription.para: Peeks at first loaded message, returns NULL if no messages have been queued.

simplesect.para: the next message, or NULL if none.

briefdescription.para: Pops a loaded message (passing ownership of the message to the caller).

detaileddescription.para: Returns NULL if no messages have been queued.

simplesect.para: the next message, or NULL if none.

briefdescription.para: Pops a loaded message inside a list link (passing ownership of the message and link to the caller).

detaileddescription.para: Returns NULL if no messages have been loaded.

simplesect.para: the next message link, or NULL if none.

briefdescription.para: Returns a popped message link, used to undo a pop.

parameterdescription.para: the link with a message in it

briefdescription.para: Checks whether the loader is confused due to bad data.

detaileddescription.para: If messages are received that are invalid, the loader gets confused and gives up permanently. This state is called "corrupted."

simplesect.para: TRUE if the loader is hosed.

briefdescription.para: Checks what kind of bad data confused the loader.

simplesect.para: why the loader is hosed, or DBUS_VALID if it isn't.

briefdescription.para: Sets the maximum size message we allow.

parameterdescription.para: the max message size in bytes

briefdescription.para: Gets the maximum allowed message size in bytes.

simplesect.para: max size in bytes

briefdescription.para: Sets the maximum unix fds per message we allow.

parameterdescription.para: the max number of unix fds in a message

briefdescription.para: Gets the maximum allowed number of unix fds per message.

simplesect.para: max unix fds

briefdescription.para: Allocates an integer ID to be used for storing application-specific data on any DBusMessage.

detaileddescription.para: The allocated ID may then be used with dbus_message_set_data() and dbus_message_get_data(). The passed-in slot must be initialized to -1, and is filled in with the slot ID. If the passed-in slot is not -1, it's assumed to be already allocated, and its refcount is incremented.
The allocated slot is global, i.e. all DBusMessage objects will have a slot with the given integer ID reserved.

parameterdescription.para: address of a global variable storing the slot

simplesect.para: FALSE on failure (no memory)

briefdescription.para: Deallocates a global ID for message data slots.

detaileddescription.para: dbus_message_get_data() and dbus_message_set_data() may no longer be used with this slot. Existing data stored on existing DBusMessage objects will be freed when the message is finalized, but may not be retrieved (and may only be replaced if someone else reallocates the slot). When the refcount on the passed-in slot reaches 0, it is set to -1.

parameterdescription.para: address storing the slot to deallocate

briefdescription.para: Stores a pointer on a DBusMessage, along with an optional function to be used for freeing the data when the data is set again, or when the message is finalized.

detaileddescription.para: The slot number must have been allocated with dbus_message_allocate_data_slot().

simplesect.para: TRUE if there was enough memory to store the data

briefdescription.para: Retrieves data previously set with dbus_message_set_data().

detaileddescription.para: The slot must still be allocated (must not have been freed).

parameterdescription.para: the slot to get data from

simplesect.para: the data, or NULL if not found

briefdescription.para: Utility function to convert a machine-readable (not translated) string into a D-Bus message type.
Utility function to convert a D-Bus message type into a machine-readable string (not translated).
Turn a DBusMessage into the marshalled form as described in the D-Bus specification.

detaileddescription.para: Generally, this function is only useful for encapsulating D-Bus messages in a different protocol.

parameterdescription.para: the location to save the marshalled form to
the location to save the length of the marshalled form to

simplesect.para: FALSE if there was not enough memory

briefdescription.para: Demarshal a D-Bus message from the format described in the D-Bus specification.

detaileddescription.para: Generally, this function is only useful for encapsulating D-Bus messages in a different protocol.

parameterdescription.para: the location to save errors to

simplesect.para: NULL if there was an error

briefdescription.para: Returns the number of bytes required to be in the buffer to demarshal a D-Bus message.

detaileddescription.para: Generally, this function is only useful for encapsulating D-Bus messages in a different protocol.

parameterdescription.para: the location to save errors to

simplesect.para: -1 if there was no valid data to be demarshalled, 0 if there wasn't enough data to determine how much should be demarshalled. Otherwise returns the number of bytes to be demarshalled

briefdescription.para: How many bits are in the changed_stamp used to validate iterators.
byte-swap the message if it doesn't match our byte order.

detaileddescription.para: Called only when we need the message in our own byte order, normally when reading arrays of integers or doubles. Otherwise should not be called since it would do needless work.

briefdescription.para: Avoid caching huge messages.
Avoid caching too many messages.
The initial buffer size of the message loader.

xrefdescription.para: this should be based on min header size plus some average body size, or something. Or rather, the min header size only, if we want to try to read only the header, store that in a DBusMessage, then read only the body and store that, etc., depends on how we optimize _dbus_message_loader_get_buffer() and what the exact message format is.

briefdescription.para: DBusMessage private implementation details.

detaileddescription.para: The guts of DBusMessage and its methods.
